newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: New Zealand tops Asia developed country forecasts.
newsitem.headline: New Zealand tops Asia developed country forecasts.

text.p: New Zealand's growth in the next few years will top that of Australia and Japan, the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) said on Wednesday.
The United Nations-affiliated commission's 1997 survey projected annual gross domestic product (GDP) growth in New Zealand at 4.8 percent from 1996 through 2000.

For Japan and Australia, the two other countries ESCAP places in the "developed" category, it projects 2.6 percent and 2.9 percent growth respectively, with Japan's figure forecast only through 1999, not the year 2000.
The report forecast annual inflation rates averaging 1.4 percent for New Zealand, 0.9 percent for Japan, and 3.4 percent for Australia.

Noting that Japan had taken a number of steps to pull itself out of recession, the report said: "With Japan's recovery completed, the three countries may be expected to continue their expansion, as is normal for mature economies."
The ESCAP report was released in Singapore through the state Trade Development Board.
